title: Stylist giving her time and talent to help others
text:
Blacktown Hospital about to open wig library for cancer patients Azal Khan, Blacktown Advocate $20 to pat a koala 
WITH a smile as big as her heart, it’s hard to believe Kathy Mandarano was once debilitated with an aggressive cancer. 
It has been a long road to recovery for the 50-year-old hairdresser who was diagnosed with head and neck cancer in 2011 but her positive attitude towards life is infectious. 
Mrs Mandarano will volunteer for Blacktown Hospital’s wig library when it opens in March. 
Patients who have hair loss from treatments can borrow a wig for a small fee for four months. 
“I lost most of my hair,’’ Mrs Mandarano said. 
“When the hair grows back, it’s actually painful to have the wig on top. 
“But I want to help people who come here with any support; I can shave their head and help style the wigs. 
“The wig is important to go out into society to be normal and not be gawked at. 
“I’m volunteering because I’ve been down that path. 
“It’s about giving that support with empathy, love, respect and honesty.” 
Mrs Mandarano was diagnosed with cancer when her GP referred her to an ear, nose and throat specialist to treat sinusitis. 
“I got my adenoids taken out and after the surgery I felt much better,’’ she said. 
“But then the specialist called me and broke the news. I couldn’t believe it.” 
She was diagnosed with a carcinoma and had a tumour in her neck. 
“Before I had radiation at Westmead Hospital, I had to have nine teeth removed.” 
She had six weeks of radiation and chemotherapy. 
A tube was inserted into her nose for eight weeks and the mother of two said it took between six months to a year to feel normal again. To donate a wig or volunteer, call 9354 2009.
